text: North-Holland

Low-level processing techniques in geophysical
image interpretation
V . ROBERTO, A. PERON
Diparrimenlo di Matematica e Informarica, Universitd di Udine, Via Zanon, 6-33100 Udine, Italy
P.L. FUMIS
Osservatorio Geofisico Sperimentale . 7'rie .ste, Italy
Received I February 1989
Abstract : The low-level processing modules of a knowledge based system for seismic-reflection image interpretation are presented :
details on their functional and structural characteristics are also given . Results of the application of each module to real image

data are extensively discussed, as well as the performances of the processing
scheme as a whole .

Key words : Image understanding, seismic data interpretation,
seismic pattern recognition, picture processing, artificial intelli-
gence.
1 . Introduction
The interpretation of geophysical data in the do-
main of seismic exploration is aimed at the investi-

gation of the earth subsurface, to detect under-
ground resources .
Several approaches have been proposed to solve
the problem of automating the data analysis, main-
ly involving image processing and pattern recogni-

tion techniques (see, for example, [4,6,7,8,9]) . Re-
markable results have been achieved concerning
specific tasks, but it can be said that most of the in-

terpretive work is still done by trained experts- This
happens because the knowledge required is largely
based on experience, and cannot be formulated in

terms of a complete mathematical model .
A new approach has been recently proposed
[5,11,13] which adopts machine vision techniques

[1] to embed in a unique framework a range of data
representations . The low-level ones, in which rele-
vant geometric/physical features in the data are en-
hanced, are combined to the high-level representa-
tions, where data are described in terms of objects,

properties and relations useful to a reasoning proc-
ess. The proposed systems, known as Knowledge
Based Systems (KBS) in the Artificial Intelligence
literature [2], do not exhibit a rigid, predefined con-
trol flow, but adapt their strategies to the actual
data, simulating the behaviour of the human expert .
The present paper reports a part of the project of
a KBS for the interpretation of seismic reflection
data: in particular, the low-level analysis modules
are introduced, and their results are shown and dis-
cussed . Section 2 contains a survey on the main fea-
tures in the data which are useful to the interpretive
tasks; goals and methods of our analysis are also re-

ported ; Section 3 gives a detailed account on the en-
hancement techniques we adopt ; results are also
shown and discussed; the same is done in Sections
4,5 and 6 for the texture analysis, line-pattern fol-

lowing and region formation processes respectively ;
an overview on the results and the performances of
our modules is reported in Section 7 .
2. Low-level analysis : goals and methods
In a seismic reflection survey, the waves generat-
ed by explosions on the earth surface, and reflected
back by the subsurface layers, are recorded as one-
dimensional seismic traces, showing the changes of

the medium impedance (velocity times density) with
depth .
After a suitable processing, the traces are put to-
gether and arranged in two-dimensional image-like
data called seismic sections .
In our case, a seismic section consists of 500 verti-
cal time samples at 4 ms sampling period, and 660
horizontal distance samples .
After discretization, a part of a section is rep-
resented as an array of grey levels (examples are
reported in Figures la, lb) like an ordinary digi-
tized image; however, it should be stressed that a
grey level may correspond either to a positive or to
a negative value in the section, as a consequence of
the physical nature of the signal itself .
As far as the interpretation tasks are concerned,

two are the main approaches being currently fol-
lowed : the structural analysis, which individuates
the geological deformations in a basin, and the stra-
tigraphic analysis [10], which provides a description

of the sedimentary history of the basin itself . Our
project follows the latter approach .
In a stratigraphic analysis, the interpreter initial-
ly focuses his/her attention on the seismic sequences,
i.e. successive and relatively concordant reflection
lines, to be interpreted as genetically homogeneous
a
Figure 1 . 256 x 256 pixel images of a part of two distinct seismic sections in the Ferrara area (Italy) ; quantization is in 256 grey levels .
Figure la shows a number of relevant line patterns (horizons, progradations) to be extracted . Figure lb is reported as an example of
image data of poor quality .
layers. The sequences are in turn composed of
simpler patterns, called horizons (reflections with a
high degree of lateral `continuity') and segments (re-
latively 'short' reflections) . Subsequently, the ana-

lyst develops an interpretation strategy, aimed at
obtaining a local geological model, in order to de-
scribe the evolution of the basin under investiga-
tion. This is done by matching a general geological

model with a geophysical model,
i.e. what can be
seen in a section in terms of physical properties of

the subsurface . By looking at the expert behaviour,
we observe that a set of actions are performed on
the data, which define what we call a low-level inter-

pretation strategy, with the following purposes :
- Extract the elementary patterns (semantic

primitives) to be used in the interpretive reasoning ;
- Suitably associate the patterns to form homo-
geneous subregions in a seismic section ;
- Select the most relevant geometric attributes to
be assigned to the subregions .
We can say that a sort of focus-of-attention is ac-
complished, whose ultimate goals are to generate or
validate hypotheses concerning the region under in-

vestigation. and activate reasoning processes .
Modeled on the expert behaviour, a low-level
strategy of analysis is present in our system too ; in
particular, a set of processes have been designed, to
produce a set of image data representations [I] as
a part of the knowledge base of the KBS under con-
struction .

We individuate three classes of processes, which
may correspond to the above quoted steps of the
human reasoning :
- Enhancement and Texture Analysis,

- Line-pattern Following,
- Region Formation .
The first set of processes individuates candidate

linear patterns in the seismic sections, by means of
enhancement and texture analysis techniques : this
is a step towards the extraction of semantic primi-
tives in the data . In addition, a partition of the
seismic section into blocks is performed, to identify
rough orientation patterns in the image, if any ; this

is done via relaxation labeling techniques
.
By line-pattern following we mean a set of proc-
esses designed to join the candidate lines into more

continuous patterns, called .segments ; this is done
using heuristic operators .
The third set of processes associates segments ac-

cording to geometric relations (e .g- parallelism); a
number of segment clusters, called
regions,
are

issued .
Regions show homogeneous geometric
properties, and may be described by a small set of

attributes .
One more point should be stressed here : our
main concern is not on achieving optimal results in
feature extraction and classification, as would be re-
quested in a pure pattern recognition scheme . Being
part of the knowledge base of a KBS, our modules
should efficiently sort out of the data the semanti-

cally relevant objects, with reasonable approxima-
tion and minimum computational cost : more re-
fined interpretive tasks will be performed in
cooperation with the high level (reasoning) proc-

esses
.
3. Enhancement
Seismic sections are noisy, and enhancement
techniques are to be used in order to improve their

quality, taking into account the interpretive tasks to
be accomplished .
Linear patterns carry all relevant information in
a seismic section . Since peaks and troughs are good
candidate points to show reflection lines in a sec-
tion, a possible approach to enhancement is using
edge detectors .
We applied such a technique (namely . Sobel and
Frei-Chen operators) but our results are not satis-

factory. as already observed in
[7] . As a matter of
fact. the maximal discontinuity points in a section
appear to be those around the zero-crossings ; then,
a differential operator has the effect of thickening

and/or duplicating a reflection line . Further thin-
ning procedures are to be applied to achieve our

goal
.

The simple technique we adopt is to keep all ex-
trema grey levels between two contiguous zero-
crossings in a trace (i .e . along vertical lines in a sec-
tion) : all other pixels are put to zero . We end up

with two representations, one of positive peaks, one
of negative. The selected values are stored in two
matrices (the peak matrices) .
Results are shown in Figures 2a and 2b, where
the positive peak matrix is shown for the sections

in Figures I a and t b respectively . As expected, ad-
jacent extrema give rise to rough linear patterns .
However, we observe that, due to noise, the peak

sequences are often interrupted ; slight misalign-
ments also occur, producing fragmented patterns .
When the data quality is particularly poor, as it
happens in Figure Ib, this results in a more evident

sparseness of the peak image patterns, which is ap-
parent from Figure 2b . Further processing is neces-
sary in any case, to identify candidate lines more
firmly .
We also observe that a strong data compression

has been achieved with low computational cost ; of
course, a considerable amount
of information has

been suppressed also, but the peak amplitudes are
preserved, and the zero-crossings arc implicitly re-

tained in our representations . We further mention
that the amplitude information will never be used
in the subsequent processing steps .
4. Texture analysis
By texture analysis we mean a set of processes
whose aim is to individuate candidate linear ele-
ments, their orientation, and subregions with domi-
nant orientations . if any.
a

Figure 2 . Positive peak images, resulting by enhancement of local maxima of the input images in Figures Ia and Ib respectively
.

The analysis is carried out in four steps :
- Run-length detection,

-Texel first labeling,
- Texel relaxation labeling,
- Block growing.
4 .1. Run-length detection
The first step follows one of the approaches to
texture reviewed in [3], namely the search for run-
length primitives, defined as the maximal collinear
connected sets of pixels . The peak matrices are ini-
tially partitioned into 16 x 16 pixel windows (tex-

els) .
Two operators are introduced [3] to work on a
texel Tj, in order to individuate run-lengths and

their orientations along three main directions : hori-
zontal, diagonal, antidiagonal .
The measures we use are :

RE

where R(l) is the number of runs of length 1, and n
is the maximal detected length
.

The first measure is better suited to evidentiate
seismic reflection events, since these show a high de-
gree of spatial coherence (i .e. long runs) . The sec-
ond is useful to single out texels with low spatial co-
herence, to be most probably excluded from further
processing .
The runs detected along the three directions are
stored in three matrices H(i,j) (the run-length matri-
ces); if H(i,j) = 1, this means that at pixel (i,j) a run
of length I originates, with the appropriate direc-
tion .
The run-length matrices act as intermediate data
structures for successive processing .
4.2 . Texel first labeling
The run-length statistics (1) and (2) can be used
to a first classification of texels T;I as predominantly
horizontal, ascendent, descendent, or non-uniform .
Confidence values are assigned to this classifica-
tion by means of a 4-ple of real numbers
where the P,,(k) are such that

zontal', `ascendent', 'descendent', 'non-uniform' re-
spectively .

The factors M,(k), M 2 act as threshold values, as
well as normalization factors, being defined by :

this is the mean value of the RE,; operator along the
horizontal direction, which occurs more frequently,
so is treated in a different way ;

diagonal directions ;
I
is the mean value of the non-uniformity operator
along the three directions of search . By N we denote
the overall number of texels .
The confidence values have been further normal-

ized in order to satisfy the conditions (3) and (4) .
The meaning of our choice for expressions (5) to
(11) is that the confidence values for a directional
labeling of texel T;; are linear combinations of the
statistics used to detect run lengths and non-unifor-
mities along the direction of label k . The real con-

stant a is chosen empirically : values ranging from
0.2 to 0.5 have been used, and labeling was found
not to be sensitive to this choice .
On the other hand, the confidence for labeling a
texel as non-uniform is the minimum among all val-
ues of the non-uniformity operator along the direc-
tions k .

Results of the texel first labeling are reported in
Figures 3a, 3b, which refer to the peak images in
Figures 2a, 2b respectively . Each texel is given the
label with highest confidence value, which is a trivi-
al way to obtain a classification . In Figures 3a, 3b
texels labeled as non-uniform are white ; the hori-
zontal ones are given a low grey level ; the descend-
ent are darker ; the ascendent are black . The cor-

rectness of the classifications can be easily checked
against Figures 2a, 2b, but the results clearly show
that our naive labeling is sensitive to noise-induced

fluctuations, being the texel size quite small
.
4 .3 . Texel relaxation labeling

In order to obtain a more stable classification, we
adopt a relaxation labeling technique
[12] . The
4-ple of confidence values of a texel is iteratively up-
dated, by taking into account its similarity with the
neighboring texels . The expression we adopt for the
P,(k) at the r-th iterative step is :
y,PJl) [I + QJ(ll
where the Q (k) are calculated as linear mappings
onto the interval [-1,1] of the sum of confidence
values of the neighboring texels
where A is the set of the four-connected texels of Ts.
Therefore, the correction factors Q'4(k) quantify the

compatibility of the neighboring texel classifica-
tions with that of the current texel, at any iterative
step .
The algorithm is found to converge in a few steps
(around ten, in the worst cases) . Results are shown
in Figures 3c, 3d, which refer to the texel labelings
in Figures 3a, 3b respectively . Labels with high con-
fidence values and good compatibility with neigh-
bours reach rapidly the highest confidence value ;

the same is verified in the opposite case
of labels
with low confidence and low compatibility, which

are given a value near zero . On the other hand, high
confidence values with low compatibility are
gradually lowered ; the same happens when the

input label is ambiguous
(i .e ., a texel is given ap-
proximately the same confidence value for each

classification) ; in all such cases, a uniform labeling
with neighbours is reached through relaxation
.

Our results show that most
of the local fluctua-
tions in the labelings have been washed out, but it

should not be forgotten that our classification is
very crude anyway .
4.4. Block growing
The last step in our texture analysis scheme is
merging texels into blocks, i.e. connected sets of tex-
els with the same label. The set is said to be con-

nected
if, for any texel pair (T,, T) in a block (we
omit the second texel index for simplicity), there ex-

ists a sequence of texels (T,,
.
., T T, + ,, . . . , T;) such
that texels (TT, + ,) belong to the block and are

eight-adjacent .
We designed a specific data structure for storage

of blocks, which is used both by the block-growing
algorithm itself, and by subsequent processing
steps .
A block may be seen as a collection of sets of hor-

izontal adjacent texels in the texel matrix ; this
means that a block can be identified by the row
index of each set, its initial column, its length .
The block data structure is outlined in Figure 7a .

Structure A is a vector of pointers, whose i-th lo-
cation addresses the i-th block descriptor : the latter

is actually a list of descriptors (the B ;) of the rows
in which the block is present . Each B ; contains a
field for the row number, and a new pointer to the
list of C-descriptors, i .e. those who memorize the in-
itial column of a sequence and its length .

The description of a block is created by inserting
the required information sequentially, after scan-
ning the data structures . In particular, the texel ma-
trix is initially scanned : a texel is selected which
does not belong to any identified block . This is the
starting texel for identifying a horizontal sequence
of adjacent elements : the lists of B- and C-descrip-
tors are updated accordingly .
5. Line-pattern following
Heuristic techniques to trace segments in a seis-

mic section have been adopted in [11], in the context
of structural interpretation, where emphasis is put
on the intensity of the reflective events : stated sim-
ply, line patterns arc found by successive additions
of adjacent local optima in the reflection intensity .

In our system we also adopt heuristic techniques,
although in the domain
of stratigraphic analysis,
where it is not of interest to evidentiate high intensi-
ty profiles ; therefore we avoid the use of grey level

thresholds . However, line-following in our case is
complicated by the presence of misalignments (os-

cillations or gaps) in the sequences
of enhanced
peaks .
Therefore a number of prescriptions must be fol-
lowed :

- Small discontinuities in a line-pattern should be
overcome ;
- Fragments belonging to distinct reflections

should not be joined ;
- Output segments should be smoothed, i .e. local

fluctuations are to be removed .
We perform two processes : Segment tracing, and
Segment composition .
5.1 . Segment tracing
Two heuristic operators perform the first line-fol-
lowing step : runs are transformed into more contin-

uous line patterns called segments, and recorded in
a data structure according to their monotonicity
properties . One operator is specialized in the trac-
ing of non-decreasing segments, the other of non-in-
creasing segments.
The appropriate operator is selected on the basis

of the local reflection directions, i .e. the labels as-
signed to blocks; moreover, blocks classified as
non-uniform are excluded by the segment tracing

step .
In these ways the outcome of texture analysis is
fully exploited .
The input representations are the run-length ma-
trices : the operators act joining runs (and not

pixels!) to build a segment .
A segment is non-ascendent if it is a collection of
horizontal and diagonal runs ; is non-descendent if it

is a sequence of horizontal and antidiagonal runs
.
If a sequence of runs shows even a short inversion
of direction, the run following procedure is stopped .
Local gaps in a sequence are carefully examined,
by analyzing the subsequent run configuration, in

a window most probably interested by the prolon-
gation of the sequence itself . In these cases, the de-
cision of bridging the gap, or stopping the run
growth is taken by looking at :
The presence in the window of runs with rele-
vant length (e.g . greater than 5 pixels) ;
-- The ratio between the overall length of runs,

and the horizontal dimension of the window ;
- The histogram of optima distribution within
the window
.
The candidate run to initialize the segment trac-
ing procedure is selected by sequentially scanning

the block structure : if a block is not classified as
non-uniform, then the corresponding part of the
horizontal run-length matrix is scanned . A run
which is found not to belong to any segment is cho-
sen as the starting point for a new segment ; the op-
erator to perform such tracing is selected according
to the label of the current block .
During the segment tracing, its coordinates are
memorized at a fixed sampling rate (e-g . 5 traces)-
A segment is described by its initial, final and inter-
mediate samples ; if needed, it may be reconstructed

joining its sample points with straight lines, thus
performing a smoothing operation . Further fea-
tures to be recorded for a segment are its monoton-
icity and length .
An appropriate data structure has been designed

for segments, and is reported in Figure 7b . Struc-
ture A is a vector of pointers to the segment descnp-
tors: segments are numbered, and the j-th position

o

respectively . Only segments of more than 8 pixels are reported .
in the vector corresponds to the j-th descriptor . The
latter is a list, whose first field contains the above
quoted informations, and the remaining ones store

the sample coordinates .
Segments are ordered according to the row and
column indices of their initial pixels .
Partial results of the segment tracing are shown
in Figures 4a, 4b, referring to the peak image in Fig-
J
Figure 5 . Final results of the segment tracing step on the image in Figure 2b (Figure 5a) : results of the segment composition, still on
the same input image, are reported in Figure 5b; only segments of more than 15 pixels are shown .
ure 2b; the two operators have been activated sepa-
rately, to detect non-ascendent and non-descendent
segments respectively, without exploiting the block
classification information .

This is done in Figure 5a, which shows the results
of the complete segment tracing scheme : both oper-
ators have been used, their activation being guided
by the block labeling results . It appears that linear
b
Figure 6 . Results of line-pattern following and region formation, respectively; the reference image is that in Figure 2a : in Figure 6a only
segments of more than 15 pixels are shown : in Figure 6b, regions with two or more segments are graphically evidentiated .
patterns are better evidentiated . However, the use

of two kinds of operators for monotonous patterns
tends to produce fragmented segments, both when

the reflection lines are long, and when their trend
is not monotonous, as it happens in Figure lb .
Therefore, segments are to be further joined, via a
composition step .
5 .2. Segment composition

We adopt heuristic operators for composition
too .
Two segments are joined if the gap between them

is considered negligible . In case of concordant seg-
ments an additional constraint is put on their

slopes, which are required to be similar .
The evaluation of the above conditions is per-
formed within a rectangular window, centered at

the end point
of a segment ; among all segments

whose starting point is in the window, the one is
chosen whose linear distance is lower . The recom-
position operation is implemented as a simple up-

dating of the segment descriptor lists
.
Results of the recomposition are shown in Fig-
ures 5b, 6a, which refer to Figures 5a, 2a respective-

ly .
More continuous patterns are issued, as ex-
pected : this is particularly relevant when the image
data quality is poor .
Further segment merging might easily be done,
by inserting more sophisticated heuristics, but the
risk to obtain unwanted effects would be increased
(e.g . to join segments belonging to different reflec-
tive events) .
6. Region formation
The last class of processes in our scheme individ-
uates spatial relations among line patterns ; seg-
ments are grouped into clusters named regions, by
which we mean attention areas in the seismic sec-

tion, whose properties are of direct semantic rele-
vance .
These areas and their features may be used as ob-
jects and attributes for reasoning processes .

The spatial relations we consider are :
- Depth-adjacency : two segments are related if

they arc not collinear, and no other segment lies in
between ;
- Parallelism : two segments are related if pairs of
sample points are distributed with a variance not
exceeding a fixed threshold value .
6 .1 . Finding related segments
To individuate adjacent segments, avoiding sys-
tematic comparisons between all possible segment

7b
.
pairs, we use the segment list (subsection 5 .1) and
exploit the order we adopted, according to the row

and column indices of the initial pixel in a segment
.
In fact, this order approximates the order of ap-
pearance of reflective events in a seismic section,
when the latter is examined starting from the earth
surface level to the interior. Therefore the segment
list is sequentially scanned ; in addition, for each col-

umn in the peak image all segments crossing that
column are recorded . When a specific segment is

considered, its initial and final columns are individ-
uated, as well as the latest segments found to cross
those columns . We say that the latter segments are
most probably depth-adjacent to the current one .

Our conjecture is reasonably well verified, but a
number of ambiguous cases have to be handled ; for
example, we sketch two such cases in Figure 8,
where it is shown how segment A can be examined
8k
before segment B, even if it lies deeper that B in the
seismic section . Simple tests on the row indices are
introduced in order to remove all ambiguities, and
update all established relations accordingly .
The data structure which stores related segments
is the adjacency matrix A(i, j), where the indices rep-
resent related pairs ; the estimated relative depth is
also recorded . We further observe that, the relation
START A

START B
AcB
AcB

Figure 8 . Typical ambiguities arising in establishing the adja-
cency relation
.
being symmetric, so is matrix A(i,j), thus allowing
to save half of the memory occupation .
Parallelism relates only segments whose projec-
tions on the horizontal axis do overlap . Within the

overlap interval, the vertical distances are meas-
ured, between segment points sampled at 3 pixel
rate .
The estimated variance of those distances is cal-
culated, and segments are related if the variance is

found not to exceed a fixed value (e.g .
1 .5 to 2 .0) .

One more threshold is used on the number of sam-
ple pairs (5, in our case) in order to obtain mean-
ingful variance estimates .
6 .2. Segment clustering

By region we mean a connected set of parallel
segments; the definition of connection follows
strictly that given in section 4.4 for block formation,

where the depth-adjacency should be used instead
of the eight-connection relation .
The region formation step is initialized by ap-

propriately choosing a segment : reasonable candi-
dates are those of maximal length among the un-
classified ones. Each adjacent segment in the
adjacency matrix is then considered, and is tested
whether is parallel or not ; if yes, it is assigned to the
region under examination, This process is iterated
until unassigned segments exist : the regions individ-
uate a partition in the segment space .

RUN-LENGTH
ARRAYS
 
l
RuNF
Results of the region formation step are reported
in Figure 6b, which refers to Figure 6a .

It is apparent that a region can be used to identify
geometrically homogeneous areas with respect to
reflective events .
For example, the horizons are clearly individuat-
ed, which delimit the overall attention area in a
seismic sequence . Moreover, regions with no domi-
nant direction, which are not interesting for inter-
pretation, are correctly excluded .
We observe that also the interfaces among differ-
ent regions are put into evidence in this way : this

is a remarkable result, since a number of interesting
elements in a sequence lie at the border between
geologically homogeneous areas
(e.g .
toplaps,
downlaps, onlaps [10]) .
As a final remark, we observe that further asso-
ciative relations might be introduced among seg-
ments, in order to extend the segment clusters ; in
addition, regions in positive and negative peak ma-
trices might be matched to obtain a more consistent

classification .
However, as in the case of segment recomposi-
tion, further merging steps may yield unwanted ef-
fects, like the cancellation of interesting interface el-
ements : after all, the high level processing can be
even more effective in reaching a consistent inter-
pretation .
7. Results and conclusions
An overview on the processes, representations
and data structures we designed is reported in Fig-
ure 9 .

Results concerning all specific processing steps
have been shown and discussed in the preceding
sections .
All representations should be seen as the iconic

elements of a knowledge base, to be complemented
by non-iconic counterparts (the analog/proposi-

resentation may be used independently, under a
control strategy which is neither predefined, nor ex-

plicitly coded, according to the paradigms of non-
procedural programming .
All modules in our scheme have been coded in
FORrRAN77, to ensure portability, and compatibility

with most of the existing program libraries in the
geophysical domain .
Two versions of the modules are currently at
work, one running on a VAX 11/780 computer, one
on a SUN 3/110 workstation, equipped with operat-
ing systems VMS and UNIX respectively. Each version

includes over 2500 lines of code .
Tests have been performed on real data, i.e. a
number of seismic sections detected in the Ferrara
area (Italy); more than twenty images from those
sections have been processed, and systematic analy-

ses are still being carried on
.
The quality of the output representations was
evaluated by three experts (two geologists, one geo-
physicist), and found satisfactory in all cases . Out-
put data quality was found to be stable against fluc-

tuations in the noise content of the input images
;
actually, in a number of test runs, the input images
were not preprocessed at all .
As far as processing time is concerned, the pro-
duction of all the representations, following the se-
quential order sketched in Figure 9, required an
average execution time of 15 to 20 seconds for the

VAX 11/780 version . The class of processes which
was found computationally most expensive is the
texture analysis, which takes roughly 50% of the
overall processing time . On the other hand, memo-
ry requirements are minimized by the use of suitable

data structures to store the output representations
;
to this respect, the use of dynamic data structures,

not present in FORTRAN77, would further optimize
our code.
In conclusion, we believe that our modules, in

their present version, perform in an efficient way the
task of semantic primitive extraction in seismic sec-
tions. More generally, a focus-of-attention scheme

has been realized on all relevant objects in the
image data, and will be used to activate symbolic
reasoning processes .

The high-level modules are presently being de-
signed .

We thank C. Chiaruttini (University di Trieste),
G. Brancolini and C . De Cillia (Osservatorio Geofi-

sico Sperimentale, Trieste) for useful discussions
and comments .
